in 5:46 , isnt the time needed still T1+T2 since you need to search through T1 first to find out that the information is not present ?  edit: nvm my bad ,for formula 1 we basically use the addition rule of probability where accessing M1, M2 and M3 are mutually exclusive events so P(A or B or C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C) , and considering that accesstime is A<B<C , the only time you would get the higher access time of B is when u miss the shorter access time of A (1-H1) , and the only time you get the higher access time of C is when you miss both A and B , but ig  it coudve been more clear that A<B<C
the arrows displayed at the sides of the memory hierarchy, do the colors represent anything(as in like red for low, green for high) or they're just arrows to show the hierarchy alone
Too fast

In formula 1 at 5:16, why do you say (1-H1)H2. This represents the probability (estimate) of not finding the data in M1 *and then* finding it in M2. Isn't the example supposed to be accessing all three memory levels simultaneously?  In that case, the formula would be: H1T1 + H2T2 + T3  Edit: i also think the second formula, for way 2, should be: H1T1 + (1-H1)H2T2 + T3 Because if processor cant find info in M1, it tries M2 but only needs T2 amount of time, not T1+T2.   Tl;dr: Way 1 should have different formula. Way 2 should have formula 1. Formula 2 is not relevant.  I'm happy to discuss or be corrected tho!

No, the formula presented in the video for way 2 is correct.  To help you understand, assume H1 is 1 . This means that I never have to go beyond first level of memory. So T_avg = T1. However as per your formula it comes out to be T1 + T3. As you do not have a coefficient on T3 it will also pop up in your calculation irrespective of values of H1 and H2. Try to think in terms of extreme values for H1 and H2 , that will give you clarity

Yes, I understand it now. Way 2 is sequential where M2 is only accessed if data isn't found in M1. The total probably of finding data in M2 is prob of not finding data in M1 * prob of finding data in M2. The effective time taken to find data in M2 is T1+T2 since we need to spend time looking in T1 first before looking for T2 seconds

had the same doubt , here's what im speculating  formula 1 in way 1 is correct , for formula 1 we  use the addition rule of probability where accessing M1, M2 and M3 are mutually exclusive events so P(A or B or C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C) , and considering that accesstime is A<B<C ,in the calculation of average, the only time you would get the higher access time of B is when u miss the shorter access time of A (1-H1) , and the only time you get the higher access time of C is when you miss both A and B (1-H1)(1-H2), in your proposed alternative formula , the average time would be greater than the largest time taken (C), which i think is most definately wrong since the process is happening in parallel  but ig  it coudve been more clear that A<B<C

Old comment but I'll answer for future readers. I don't think it can happen. H3 isn't explicitly written because it's assumed to be 100%. H1 and H2 are just the chances of finding the information you want in different memory levels, but if they're neither in M1 or M2 then they're definitely in M3, the secondary memory.  Now I'm definitely second guessing my answer because null reference exceptions are very common errors that can creep up in many programming languages. Specifically when code is executed at runtime that attempts to reference a variable that contains no value. Would be interesting to hear from others.

yes You might be wondering where is H3 hit ratio ?

h1 is hit ratio, that is the probability of finding the data inside m1. So, in contrast to that, the probability of the processor unable to find the data inside m1 is miss ratio: 1-h1 e.g.  In case of a coin toss,  the probability of finding head is 1/2 And the probability of not finding head(i.e. finding tail) is (1-probability of finding head)=(1-1/2)=1/2 I hope this helps! They also mentioned it @5:31 timestamp. Go through it.
Well, It's not the case that one is better than another. They are different approaches of memory interfacing. It depends on the implementation we are going with.
